children.subject: It is indeed fully an online course.

Hi Gustavo,

Can you please confirm for students that this is an online course?

Nicole

Thank you for the offer, but I already have the course set up for this time around and don't really have the time to rearrange things with new material. It sounds interesting though, so I'd be happy to give it a shot for the next round.

Great, yeah, just let us know :) 

We'd also be interested in getting professor input on some things if you ever have any free time, so we'll reach out at some point haha. 

Nice job with this class -- it was very much needed!

Not actually a professor sorry to say, I'm just an incoming sophomore who didn't have a lot of coding experience coming in and wanted to do something to help others who are in that position (I've edited the original post to make that clear, because being addressed as Professor De Leon or Mr. De Leon is downright awkward...).

If you need any help or want collaborators to help develop courseware, I'm the head of a UC Berkeley startup composed of a team of CS students here and we've been doing some development of projects in Python. These projects, worksheets, and lectures are developed for the HS level and thus lack some of 61A's most intricate details from the beginning through recursion, but there is a distinct 61A flavor and similarities. 

In addition, a developed 3 hour workshop that utilizes online activities starting with drag-and-drop and graduating to python is on Piazza, if that's something you'd be somewhat interested in looking at/integrating with something like this.

Workshops like this were designed to give a briefer intro to CS and develop an appreciation for the art of problem solving than a year long AP course or even semester long CS 10, so it's something that fits into what you're trying to do.

Contact us at P.ShiftEducation@gmail.com if you're at all interested :)
Sorry, but it doesn't give any units. It's just an online program you can take to prepare for CS classes if you have no coding experience.
Nope, we made it self paced, so you can feel free to jump in at any point during the summer and work your way through as much of it as you can!
Is it too late to sign up now?

history.content:
Hey there!

I'm an incoming sophomore here at Berkeley, and with the help of Tiffany Reardon, the Director for EECS Diversity & Achievement, I've put together an Intro to Coding course for students with zero or near to coding experience who want to prepare themselves over the summer to ensure they can do well in CS 61A (the first class you'll be taking as an EECS or CS major).
 
This program is officially running from June 13th to August 19th, but it's really self-paced so you can feel free to jump in at any point during the summer. It's set up so it doesn't take more than a few hours of your time each day to meet the weekly goals. That said, don't worry about falling behind, while of course I'd prefer that everyone keep pace and finish the course in its entirety, you can work at your own pace and whatever you do manage to find the time to do will help you be that much more prepared come Fall Semester.
 
The course will consist of two parts: learning Ruby using Chris Pine's Learn to Program, and then refining your knowledge of the language and your ability to solve problems by completing challenging exercises on exercism.io. Ruby was chosen because I know how hard it can be to start programming, and this book is by far the best I've found for a true introduction to programming. Learning in Ruby also has the nice benefit of it being an extremely similar language to Python, the language you will be using in your first class.
 
Beyond learning how to code, I'll also help you setup your GitHub account, a version control resource that is used by essentially everyone, and really makes your life a lot easier later on.
 
If you are interested in taking part in this, please fill out this form with your name and an email address you check regularly so we can get in contact!
 
 
Best wishes,
 
Gustavo De Leon
history.subject: Intro to Coding Summer Prep Course
